content.description:
This route starts with 1-2 hard to see bolts to the right of Pope's on a Date.  Follow the runout slab to the arching face above the roof system.  Join Pope on a Date for the final crux moves to the anchor.

Rap with a 60M rope...
content.location:
The first bolted route on the SE corner of

Bath Rock

.

content.description:
This is an exciting and interesting route for a sport climb.  The rock quality is a little lacking, but the moves are fun to work out.

Follow three easy to see bolts through a ledgey headwall.  Work up the white slab to a cruxy mantle above the lip of the roof.  A final fiction/tension crux leads the the anchors. Be careful of the rope drag due to the wandering nature of the route.
content.location:
The second bolted route left of the SE corner of

Bath Rock

.

content.description:
This pumpy route is located on the south face of

Bath Rock

. Do a 4th class approach to the upper ledge below a small tree. Traverse straight right for 20-25ft to the first bolt. (optional #1 camalot) Follow well protected climbing through a small bulge to the main event.  A large 6-8ft roof with huecos is the crux. The route finding is difficult, since the clock is ticking.  Pick the right path and you might be a saint.
content.protection: 10-12 bolts with optional #1 camalot and a few long slings...
content.location: This route is located on the southern overhangs.  Follow a line of bolts through a large roof.  These start just to the right of a small bush after the 4th class approach.

content.description:
Actually, on the south east side of Bath Rock - staring you in the face every time you drive up the road.  Starts on a slab where a tongue of rock touches the ground.  First pitch is 5.7 and has two or three places for protection.  Belay in a scooped out dish below a steep headwall with a mid size cam.

Move right and climb the steep headwall using two crack systems for protection.  Probably not a good pitch as your first 5.8 trad lead.  A little grainie near the top, but should clean up if anyone ever does it again.

Belay on top by looping the rope around a large block on the edge.
content.protection: Cams to 3", a couple of small cams, full set of nuts. Runners to straighten out the rope drag.
content.location:
Walk across the road and follow the trail along the east to south side of the rock.  Just after a tree (in the picture), head up a tongue of rock looking for diagnoling cracks.  Great face and crack climbing and all trad.

Walk down the rebar route on the back side.

content.description: A short route that is very steep, especially for the City.  Scramble up high to the first bolt.  Easy climbing leads to an overhung wall with huge holds and large moves. After clipping the last bolt on the face, you run into the crux. Throw into a slippery under cling and attempt to mantle out the dihedral to the chains. Holds and feet are sharp without much polish. Super fun!
content.location: On the South face of Bath Rock.  Sandwiched between two 11a's (Prey for Me & The Pope Got Pumped). Scramble up some ledges to belay.
